Here are two things I'd really like to see:

1) Recovery cost dependent on distance from KSC AND Biome.

2) A "Return To Hangar" option to store ships. This is free if the ship is on the runway or launch pad, costs a small amount of money (like 1% of the cost of the craft) from the KSC biome, and is unavailable anywhere else.

Isn't that what the Falcon-9 is intended to do anyway? (the F9 1st stage does one orbit then lands at/near the launch site), well that's why I brought it up as behaviour example anyway.

For KSP you'd need it to top out high enough past 70Km that you can swap over to s2 and circ, then switch back and land with s1

Or even circ with s1 disconnect the payload in a stable orbit, then s1 does its own deorbit burn and lands

Either way, going to be a lot of budgetary gymnastics for an efficient space program now!

The first stage of the Falcon 9 does nothing NEAR a full orbit, it's not even close to escaping the atmosphere, it's really just to lift the second stage into a high altitude with lower drag. Even the second stage is sub-orbital, but the first stage is actually supposed to bleed off it's speed and return to the launch pad once they are done testing it, the second stage would probably end up being a mid Atlantic recovery (or Gulf of Mexico if launched from their proposed Texas spaceport).

Oh god, that! All of my yes. It sucks that I have nowhere to store a vessel - I have a hanger for gods sake, can't you just open up the door and let me in for a bit?

I think this 'Return to Hanger' would incur a very small cost, as you said, and leave the vessel as it was - same amount of fuel, same parts etc.. But I think the game would have to keep track of what parts you already own because if you swap out a few engines while in the hanger, it would either be free (because the game sees it as your existing vessel) or cost the full amount of the craft (because the game sees it as a new vessel). I have a gut feeling that the game can, as it stands right now, only recognise a 'new' vessel and charge you as needed. Like I said, make it remember what parts were already bought and only charge me for new parts. That way, I'm still paying for the fuel and payload but the plane that I've already paid for is still mine and if a wing breaks upon landing, I can pay to replace it.

That said, we get to a grey area where if you crash upon landing and are only left with, say, the cockpit, it'd be cheaper to Return to Hanger and rebuild your plane from there than it would be to recover it and relaunch it again.

Max has confirmed that parts that you don't actually "ride down" will not be counted as recovered and will adhere to the existing deletion rules pertaining to dispelled parts.

The craft would not be deleted so long as it had power and was operating according to a program, and would be recoverable upon landing presuming the instructions worked correctly.

Seems like reusability will be a bit difficult to reap a lot of benefit from, whether you're a spaceplane or rocket user. Multi-stage rockets would seem to be unable to easily recover spent stages even if they're equipped to be safely landable, a bit of compromise in the timing of staging events would be needed to make everything recoverable. Spaceplanes and other reusable SSTOs can only be reused for the minimum cost by using a refueling tanker and installing payload by using a ground crew, otherwise they're subject to the same recovery percentage as everything else.

This actually strikes me as a good balance. Reusability is difficult to make work well in real life, and it is so in KSP. Players who want to reap the most benefit of reusability will have to compromise staged designs or maintain and operate ground crew for SSTOs.

It is a bit odd that one of the critical technologies for a reusable space program will be rover wheels; ground crew is much more capable with wheels.
In my experience, even without rover wheels (just with the airplane unpowered wheels), you can still move around pretty easy using RCS blocks for thrust.

It wasn't a suggestion so much as a comment on the described system. You can get good reusability but you have to work a bit for it. If the recovery mechanic worked the way some are suggesting (i.e. 100% recovery), we'd basically have to use reusable craft to be economically efficient; I like that the system doesn't railroad players that way and supports different play styles.

In another thread talking about recovery mechanics, I suggested that there be a line of tech nodes that grant ever better recovery percentages; this struck me as a good compromise in that players who aren't interested in reusability can still be economically competitive, while players who do want reusability can pursue those techs and recover most or all of their reusable ships' cost.
